731930f-a.title: Islands - Coney Island - Brooklyn - Boardwalk.
731930f-a.text:
ghe New Boardwalk at Coney Island
Long strtches of the southern shore of Brooklyn and Cueens boroughs are sandy beaches where ocear surf bathing is popular. The beet known of these beaches is at Coney lIsland; others are at Brighton, Manhattan, and Rockaway. A warm Sunday or holiday will bring half a million New Yorkers and visitors to these beaches. The picture shows a portion of the bomrdwalk at Coney Island, opened last year- 83 feet wide and a
mile and a half lons-,,
July. 22, 1923  hnderwood and Underwood

731953f-a.title: Islands - Coney Island beach.
731953f-a.text:
(1)
Coney Island Beach, showing a view westward from about the foot of Ocean Parkway. Note the small crowd. This is so only during week days. On week ends and holidays this beach is so congested that one can
scarcely find a place to sit.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from another angle, showing only one of the rock piles extending
from the beach.
Auguet 14, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

732002f-b.title: Islands - Coney Island - [Riegelmann boardwalk - Steeplechase Park - West 16th Street in Brooklyn.]
732002f-b.text:
(1)
Coney Island (Reigelmann) Boardwalkc, at the N.W. corner of West 16th Street, showing a portion of George C. Tilyou's Steeplechase Park. Shown on the right, is a view morthward on West 16th Street, emphasizing the west side. The 3-story frame house, is at the N.E. corner of Surf
Ave.
August 6, 1932.
P.. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing a more extensive view westward.
July 6, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
